segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 16
segments.en: Linked Discourses 16

segments.pli: 1. Kassapavagga
segments.en: 1. Kassapa

segments.pli: 3. Candūpamāsutta
segments.en: 3. Like the Moon

segments.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ viharati.
segments.en: At Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: “Candūpamā, bhikkhave, kulāni upasaṅkamatha—
segments.en: “Mendicants, you should approach families like the moon:

segments.pli: apakasseva kāyaṃ, apakassa cittaṃ, niccanavakā kulesu appagabbhā.
segments.en: withdrawn in body and mind, always the newcomer, and never impudent.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso jarudapānaṃ vā olokeyya pabbatavisamaṃ vā nadīviduggaṃ vā—
segments.en: Suppose a person were to look down at an old well, a rugged cliff, or an inaccessible riverland.

segments.pli: apakasseva kāyaṃ, apakassa cittaṃ;
segments.en: They’d withdraw their body and mind.

segments.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, candūpamā kulāni upasaṅkamatha—
segments.en: In the same way, you should approach families like the moon:

segments.pli: apakasseva kāyaṃ, apakassa cittaṃ, niccanavakā kulesu appagabbhā.
segments.en: withdrawn in body and mind, always the newcomer, and never impudent.

segments.pli: Kassapo, bhikkhave, candūpamo kulāni upasaṅkamati—
segments.en: Kassapa approaches families like the moon:

segments.pli: apakasseva kāyaṃ, apakassa cittaṃ, niccanavako kulesu appagabbho.
segments.en: withdrawn in body and mind, always the newcomer, and never impudent.

segments.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave,
segments.en: What do you think, mendicants?

segments.pli: kathaṃrūpo bhikkhu arahati kulāni upasaṅkamitun”ti?
segments.en: What kind of mendicant is worthy of approaching families?”

segments.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaṃyeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
segments.en: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā ākāse pāṇiṃ cālesi.
segments.en: Then the Buddha waved his hand in space.

segments.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ayaṃ ākāse pāṇi na sajjati na gayhati na bajjhati;
segments.en: “Mendicants, this hand is not stuck or held or caught in space.

segments.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci bhikkhuno kulāni upasaṅkamato kulesu cittaṃ na sajjati na gayhati na bajjhati:
segments.en: In the same way, when approaching families, a mendicant’s mind is not stuck or held or caught, thinking:

segments.pli: ‘labhantu lābhakāmā, puññakāmā karontu puññānī’ti;
segments.en: ‘May those who want material possessions get them, and may those who want merit make merits!’

segments.pli: yathāsakena lābhena attamano hoti sumano, evaṃ paresaṃ lābhena attamano hoti sumano;
segments.en: They’re just as pleased and happy when others get something as they are when they get something.

segments.pli: evarūpo kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu arahati kulāni upasaṅkamituṃ.
segments.en: This kind of mendicant is worthy of approaching families.

segments.pli: Kassapassa, bhikkhave, kulāni upasaṅkamato kulesu cittaṃ na sajjati na gayhati na bajjhati:
segments.en: When Kassapa approaches families, his mind is not stuck or held or caught, thinking:

segments.pli: ‘labhantu lābhakāmā, puññakāmā karontu puññānī’ti;
segments.en: ‘May those who want material possessions get them, and may those who want merit make merits!’

segments.pli: yathāsakena lābhena attamano hoti sumano;
segments.en: He’s just as pleased and happy when others get something as he is when he gets something.

segments.pli: evaṃ paresaṃ lābhena attamano hoti sumano.
Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave,
segments.en: What do you think, mendicants?

segments.pli: kathaṃrūpassa bhikkhuno aparisuddhā dhammadesanā hoti, kathaṃrūpassa bhikkhuno parisuddhā dhammadesanā hotī”ti?
segments.en: What kind of mendicant’s teaching is pure, and what kind is impure?”

segments.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaṃyeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
segments.en: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

segments.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” they replied.

segments.pli: Bhagavā etadavoca:
segments.en: The Buddha said this:

segments.pli: “Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃcitto paresaṃ dhammaṃ deseti:
segments.en: “Whoever teaches Dhamma to others with the thought:

segments.pli: ‘aho vata me dhammaṃ suṇeyyuṃ, sutvā ca pana dhammaṃ pasīdeyyuṃ, pasannā ca me pasannākāraṃ kareyyun’ti;
segments.en: ‘Oh! May they listen to the teaching from me. When they’ve heard it, may they gain confidence in the teaching and demonstrate their confidence to me.’

segments.pli: evarūpassa kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno aparisuddhā dhammadesanā hoti.
segments.en: Such a mendicant’s teaching is impure.

segments.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃcitto paresaṃ dhammaṃ deseti:
segments.en: Whoever teaches Dhamma to others with the thought:

segments.pli: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhīti.
segments.en: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

segments.pli: Aho vata me dhammaṃ suṇeyyuṃ, sutvā ca pana dhammaṃ ājāneyyuṃ, ājānitvā ca pana tathattāya paṭipajjeyyun’ti.
segments.en: Oh! May they listen to the teaching from me. When they’ve heard it, may they understand the teaching and practice accordingly.’

segments.pli: Iti dhammasudhammataṃ paṭicca paresaṃ dhammaṃ deseti, kāruññaṃ paṭicca anuddayaṃ paṭicca anukampaṃ upādāya paresaṃ dhammaṃ deseti.
segments.en: So they teach others because of the natural excellence of the teaching, out of compassion, kindness, and sympathy.

segments.pli: Evarūpassa kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno parisuddhā dhammadesanā hoti.
segments.en: Such a mendicant’s teaching is pure.

segments.pli: Kassapo, bhikkhave, evaṃcitto paresaṃ dhammaṃ deseti:
segments.en: Kassapa teaches Dhamma to others with the thought:

segments.pli: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhīti.
segments.en: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

segments.pli: Aho vata me dhammaṃ suṇeyyuṃ, sutvā ca pana dhammaṃ ājāneyyuṃ, ājānitvā ca pana tathattāya paṭipajjeyyun’ti.
segments.en: Oh! May they listen to the teaching from me. When they’ve heard it, may they understand the teaching and practice accordingly.’

segments.pli: Iti dhammasudhammataṃ paṭicca paresaṃ dhammaṃ deseti, kāruññaṃ paṭicca anuddayaṃ paṭicca anukampaṃ upādāya paresaṃ dhammaṃ deseti.
segments.en: Thus he teaches others because of the natural excellence of the teaching, out of compassion, kindness, and sympathy.

segments.pli: Kassapena vā hi vo, bhikkhave, ovadissāmi yo vā panassa kassapasadiso, ovaditehi ca pana vo tathattāya paṭipajjitabban”ti.
segments.en: I will exhort you with the example of Kassapa or someone like him. You should practice accordingly.”

segments.pli: Tatiyaṃ.

suttaplex.blurb: Kassapa approaches families like the moon, with humility, keeping his distance, and not getting involved. So when he teaches, it is with pure intentions.
